trial_identification.studytitle: Intake of free sugars and micronutrient dilution in Australian adults
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Intake of free sugars and micronutrient dilution in Australian adults

interventions.interventions:
The independent variable is the intake of free sugar, which is defined by the WHO as all monosaccharides and disaccharides added to foods by the manufacturer, cook, or consumer, plus sugars naturally present in honey, syrups, and fruit juices.
Each participant completed two 24-hr recall, on two non-consecutive days, using the Automated Multiple-Pass Method (AMPM) developed by the Agricultural Research Service of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)

primaryOutcome.outcome: The primary dependent variable is the micronutrient intake. This was translated from the dietary intake data of the survey, which was collected from two 24-hr recalls. The dietary intake data were then translated into nutrient intake using the AUSNUT2011-13 food composition database.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: two 24-hr recall periods on non-consecutive days

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Food group intake data. This was from the dietary intake data of the survey, which was collected using two 24-hr recalls.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: two 24-hr recall periods on non-consecutive days

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Usual residents of private dwellings in urban and rural areas of Australia, covering about 97% of the people living in Australia. Dietary data from those whose age was equal to or greater than 19 years old were included in this analysis.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Implausible dietary intake, as determined by the Goldberg cut-off method

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: 5S-14, Kadoorie Biological Sciences Bldg, The University of Hong Kong, 1 Pokfulam Road, Pokfulam, Hong Kong

fundingsource.fundingname: Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Sirius Building, Furzer Street, Woden Town Centre, ACT 2606

ethicsAndSummary.summary: There has been an increasing concern on the possible negative effects of excessive sugar intake, particularly added sugar, on the quality of diet and health status. Added sugar was found to be associated with poorer nutrient intake. A similar impact on micronutrient dilution was expected from free sugar as an estimation of approximately 10 g difference between added sugar and free sugar intake was found in the Australian population. The hypotheses of the current analysis include: a) the WHO cut-offs were not suitable for assessing micronutrient dilution; and b) micronutrient dilution is not evident until %energy from free sugars reaches 25% or above.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2016, Australian Health Survey: Consumption of added sugars, 2011-12 , cat. no. 4364.0.55.011, viewed 16 June 2016. URL: http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/4364.0.55.011main+features12011-12
ethicsAndSummary.publicnotes: Ethics approval were not required since this is a secondary analysis.
